title: Can Manamune please be buffed?
body:
{{item:3004}} Manamune has been severely left behind by somewhat recent changes.  It was left out of the AD item revamp and passed over when {{item:3003}} Archangel's Staff was made more slot efficient.  Buffing Manamune will help several of the least popular and most underpowered champions in the game.  It will also help provide consistent itemization options since it is currently inferior to its sister item, Archangel Staff.

Below are lists of the champions most frequently building Muramana/Manamune.
{{item:3042}} Muramana:
http://i.imgur.com/rL67zFt.jpg

{{item:3004}} Manamune:
http://i.imgur.com/8GE8GHX.jpg

As you can see above, Manamune/Muramana is currently only being built by 5 out of 128 champions in the game. The number of occurrences after {{champion:6}} Urgot and {{champion:110}} Varus fall off to insignificant numbers.  Meta-breaking AD Malzahar and AD Blitzcrank builds make up most of the remaining occurences, with a few remaining Kog'Maws building it.

{{champion:6}} Urgot, {{champion:110}} Varus, and {{champion:96}} Kog'Maw are all within the bottom 5 least popular marksmen, even when including their play rate in other lanes/roles (AP Varus, AP Kog'maw, Bruiser Urgot, etc.).  

{{champion:6}} Urgot and {{champion:83}} Yorick are *the* two least popular champions in the game, and have under 50% winrates despite typically only being played by experienced players due to their small playerbase.  

Champions like {{champion:80}} Pantheon and {{champion:121}} Kha'Zix really want what is offered by this item, but aren't building it often because of how weak it is in its current state.  A fully stacked Muramana is harder to obtain than most alternative items, yet doesn't currently give much of a power spike due to its poor base AD compared to other AD items.

I think this item can be safely buffed for an easy victory for the Riot balance team. Here are some suggested changes:

{{item:3004}} 
{{item:1037}} Pickaxe replaced by {{item:1038}} B. F. Sword in recipe.
Combine Cost ~~775~~ ⇒ 1050 (Total Cost ~~2400~~ ⇒ 3100; This is the same total cost as Archangel's Staff)
AD ~~25~~ ⇒ 50
Base Mana Regen ~~25%~~ ⇒ 50%
Mana Charge: Grants ~~4~~ ⇒ 6 maximum Mana (max +750 Mana) for each basic attack, spell cast, and Mana expenditure (occurs up to 2 times every 8 seconds). **Grants 1 maximum Mana every 8 seconds.**

{{item:3042}} 
AD ~~25~~ ⇒ 50
Base Mana Regen ~~25%~~ ⇒ 50%

Most of these changes help make Manamune more consistent as the AD equivalent of Archangel's Staff. I feel that Archangel's Staff was greatly improved when its recipe was updated and it became a more slot efficient item. I'd like the same treatment for Manamune. 

With the AD item revamp, B.F. Sword became cheaper, making it a more convenient item to build early on. I feel this would not homogenize {{item:3004}} Manamune with {{item:3508}} Essence Reaver since the AD item revamp helped distinguish Essence Reaver.  Essence Reaver would remain *the* CDR item for crit users, while Manamune would be distinguished by its early mana Tear of the Goddess build path, Awe passive, and Muramana toggle effect. This would also bring the number of B.F. Sword items ({{item:3004}} {{item:3031}} {{item:3072}} {{item:3508}}) closer in line with the number of Needlessly Large Rod items ({{item:3003}} {{item:3089}} {{item:3116}} {{item:3285}} {{item:3157}}).

The changes to the base mana regen and flat AD are to match Archangel's Staff and to compensate for the increased build cost. Increasing AD to 50 would make {{item:3004}} Manamune's base AD roughly 77% of the base AD of {{item:3508}} or {{item:3031}}.  For comparison, {{item:3003}} Archangel's Staff provides 80 base AP, which is exactly 80% of the base AP provided by {{item:3285}}, {{item:3157}}, or {{item:3116}}.  If Manamune were buffed to 55 base AD, that would be a little under 85% of the base AD of {{item:3508}} or {{item:3031}}.

The buff to stacking rate from 4 to 6 mana is to help {{item:3004}} Manamune users stack up a little easier. {{item:3003}} Archangel's Staff gains 8 mana per expenditure, and while Manamune also gains stacks for autoattacks, both items are limited to 2 stack gains per 8 seconds.  This means that even with this buff, Manamune would still have a lower maximum mana gain per 8 seconds (12 vs 16). 

The inclusion of {{item:3070}} Tear of the Goddess's passive +1 mana stack per 8 seconds in the upgraded items would also be very helpful. It is fairly rare for an item to lose this kind of functionality when upgraded, and is somewhat annoying. Tear of the Goddess is actually able to gain a higher amount of mana than Manamune per 8 seconds (9 vs 8), which is somewhat counter-intuitive since players expect upgraded items to be completely superior to their components. This specific change could also be applied to Archangel's Staff, which would also help mana hungry mages that build Archangel's and are struggling in mid lane, such as Karthus and Cassiopeia.

Thanks for reading! Please comment and participate in the poll. If you agree that Manamune should be buffed, please upvote the thread for visibility. If you would like Manamune to be buffed but in a different way than I suggested, feel free to post your own idea(s) here.

Using 6% current health damage instead of 3% max health damage actually gives MORE dps. It rewards having heavy damage on autos, as if your first auto deals 1000 damage (including botrk) and the second hit deals like 960 damage (the target is assumed to have 2000 hp), then the enemy champion will basically have been dealt MORE damage than expected, as over those two hits the average %health damage was actually 4.5%. Essentially it is exactly what you said, a softening up mechanic that allows you to eventually kill a foe with your own damage.

The balance here comes from dealing more damage to high health targets. In essence, the botrk itself or liandries itself is not a champion killer. The items' usages would change significantly if they were able to kill champions on their own.

If they buffed a niche item, there's only 2 outcomes.

+It's reworked to become a standard item which everyone can use.
+It gets a big buff to make it attractive to everyone, which then becomes seriously OP on some niche users, then nerfed back to oblivion.

I think there is a third possibility which would result from a proper numbers buff:

+It gets a sizable buff to make it attractive to its entire intended class, non-crit AD mana users. Its currently severely underpowered niche users temporarily rise 1-5% winrate. Assuming there is no unnecessary knee-jerk nerf, this results in an increase in popularity by 1-3%, driving their winrate back down by 1-3% as inexperienced players pick up the champions. After a few months, winrates/popularity stabilize at a totally reasonable (and still somewhat underpowered) level of ~2% popularity and ~49% winrate for {{champion:83}} {{champion:6}} instead of the current 0.7% popularity and 47% winrate. 

The only niche users that could be call for concern are {{champion:126}} and {{champion:81}}. Ezreal is currently having much more success with {{item:3508}} anyways. Jayce is currently being considered for buffs according to another poster in this thread:

> When asked if they have any plans to look at Jayce following the 5.22 patch, Meddler noted:
> 
>     "Yeah, we think we'll need to do something for Jayce early next year. Itemization changes in 5.22 seem to have hit him pretty hard. Might look at Manamune and/or Muramana buffs, still figuring out which lever's best to use (is it a lack of power on kit or a lack of support from other systems)."

Considering all of this, I think that it is pretty safe for Manamune to be buffed. If Ezreal or Jayce were overbuffed, they could be slightly directly nerfed in compensation, still resulting in a net buff overall. Champions like {{champion:121}} Kha'Zix would gain a new viable itemization option but would be unlikely to oversynergize with it.

Good idea.

The only thing I'd disagree with is the stack change - instead of making it potentially faster to stack by increasing the stack count, I would make the number of "charges" one could have at once be higher. The problem most people have with the stack rate isn't the actual rate-of-return, but rather how you need a valid target to trigger the effect. By allowing more stacks to be stored, you decrease the wasted stacks without allowing high-sustain champions (or people paired with sustain supports) from stacking it too quickly. For example:

Mana Charge: Grants 4 maximum Mana (max +750 Mana) for each basic attack, spell cast, and Mana expenditure (occurs up to 5 times every 20 seconds).

> [{quoted}](name=Krinu,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=E4nXhtkd,comment-id=000b,timestamp=2015-12-27T08:21:03.622+0000)
>
> Mana Charge: Grants 4 maximum Mana (max +750 Mana) for each basic attack, spell cast, and Mana expenditure (occurs up to 5 times every 20 seconds).

That's a good thought, and I could imagine something like that working.  Just a couple questions and concerns:

1) Would Archangel's Staff receive the same QOL change or be left as-is?

2) Aren't those numbers still a bit low compared to Archangel's Staff? Archangel's Staff would still produce up to twice as many stacks over the full 20 seconds. Is there really a reason that Archangel's Staff needs to be twice as fast to charge? Some mages have spells that are even more convenient for charging than autoattacks, such as Singed's poison, Anivia's ult, and Karthus' Q + E.

You're not considering several things:

* __The effectiveness of AP is directly tied to Mana expenditure.__  Therefore, it makes sense that an AP item with a %current Mana active needs have better stats gold-wise than an AD item with a %current Mana active, because users of the AP mana item tend to have less mana at any given moment.
* __Seraph's active is defensive; Muramana's is offensive.__ Since both are built on characters who are looking to BE offensive, primarily, Muramana's holds much greater value as a big powerspike reward for completion of the item. This makes its active much more powerful even if numbers-wise the two seem similar; as a result, it makes sense Muramana's stats are worse gold-wise.
* __Attack Speed as a multiplier for AD is easier to acquire than CDR as a multiplier for AP.__ Most AD champions who even build AS at all only build 1 AS item + Berserker Greaves, if that. The only champs who build more usually do so because their kit has powerful on-hit effects, and those champions typically aren't as interested in stacking AD (= this item doesn't factor in their purchase decisions). Meanwhile mages have to commit at least 2 item slots to get enough CDR to create a significant multiplier, usually more, and their 20% CDR options also focus on mana regen which has low-synergy with Seraph's Insight passive.
* __Maximum attainable stat analysis is unrealistic at best.__ This should be obvious, but very few games make it to level 18, 6 items. Even fewer have Seraph's + triple-stacked RoA. By the time most games end, the difference in gold value between the two items is far less exaggerated.
* ___AD itemization is not meant to directly parallel AP itemization and therefore should not be directly compared to AP itemization.___ This is the big one. Not only would this make itemization extremely bland, they are two fundamentally different stats that deserve different tools. Just because Manamune builds from Tear and Seraph's builds from Tear doesn't mean the two should be balanced against each other. Instead of comparing it to AP items which have a completely different "audience" to AD items, try comparing Manamune to other items its users might reasonably buy. If Manamune is weak, what are people preferring to buy over it? How can Manamune *distinguish* itself from those items, or how can its numbers be changed to play up its fantasy? I don't think Manamune's fantasy is "highest AD item in the game," so why should we try to emphasize that about it? This is my opinion, but the "stacking power" theme and the "big payoff" theme of the item both seem like sound places to buff Manamune and make it more attractive than, say, Youmuu's.
